# EVALUATION PROMPT (Sharper, more critical, human‑aligned v3)

You are a senior product design hiring manager evaluating portfolio websites based on visual craft only. Judge only what is visible in the provided page(s)/images. Do not infer quality from brands, content, or reputation.

## Evaluation Rules

1. Scoring posture (critical, calibrated, evidence‑first):
   - Default anchor is 3 (Average/Competent). Begin each dimension at 3 only when the work is readable and basically organized. Move up or down strictly on visible evidence.
   - Break test: before moving above 3, find at least 3 attempts at potential flaws (e.g., casing drift, crop cut‑offs, width drift, button/type mismatch). If you can find 3+ credible issues, hold at 2–3.
   - Be skeptical of “tidy but generic.” Default‑ish type, boilerplate layouts, or lightly styled templates should land at 2–3 unless you see clear bespoke tuning and micro‑craft (see Rule 2).
   - Do not award 4–5 for “not broken.” Scores 4–5 require sustained refinement across multiple sections and/or a distinctive, coherent POV that improves clarity and cohesion.
   - Evidence‑limited views: When only a single hero or single section is visible, cap each dimension at 3 unless either the Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check or the Elevated Basics Check passes (see Rule 2). Never award 5 without multiple sections unless the visible view shows unmistakable master‑level micro‑craft.
   - Apply caps from red flags (Rules 7 and 9). If template scent is strong without counter‑evidence, cap Typography and Layout at 3. If sloppy image cues ≥3, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mismatched whites/mats cause flicker. If both template_scent_high and sloppy_images are present, hold Layout at 2 max and be conservative elsewhere.

2. Two ways a single refined view can justify a 4 (stricter; verify each signal; any disqualifier below fails the check):
   - Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check (pass when ≥5 signals are present):
     - Tuned neutrals (off‑black/off‑white; borders/shadows with gentle hue shifts and controlled values).
     - Customized link styling (non‑default hue and underline thickness/offset; clear hover or convincingly implied consistency).
     - Measured typographic rhythm (predictable scale steps; stable baseline; no widows/orphans; intentional hyphenation and rags; consistent punctuation and casing).
     - Intentional spacing system (e.g., 4/8/12 multiples; even row rhythm; no accidental half‑gutter gaps).
     - Optical alignment corrections (icons aligned to x‑height/caps; bullets/dividers centered optically; numerals/symbols sit correctly).
     - Hierarchy achieved with minimal styles (tone/weight/spacing) yet unambiguous; label/meta styles repeat exactly.
     - Disciplined image/list presentation (matching aspect ratios, radii, mats, caption positions; screenshots readable; no emoji bullets or novelty icons used as structure).
     - Cohesive bespoke touches (editorial serif paired with care; caret/arrow icons aligned to cap height; button strokes matching surrounding type weight; no default blue).
   - Elevated Basics Check (for default‑leaning but carefully tuned designs; pass when ≥6 signals are present):
     - Comfortable measures (45–80ch body) and consistent 1.3–1.7 leading; display leading tighter but non‑colliding.
     - Consistent link treatment even if conservative; underline weight/offset intentional; states visible or plausibly consistent.
     - Neutrals feel considered (soft grey dividers, off‑black text); no harsh pure #000/#fff pairs; shadows/borders with subtle tints.
     - Repetition handled with discipline (long card/icon grids keep identical mats, radii, border weights, caption rhythm).
     - Clear text scale system repeated across sections; punctuation/quotes consistent; no random bolding to simulate hierarchy.
     - Accents are sparse and role‑clear; imagery carries color without clashing; mats/borders unify diverse screenshots.
     - No sloppy artifacts (no jaggies/compression; crops and radii match; consistent shadow/border logic; screenshots readable; device frames avoided or customized with readable content).
   - Disqualifiers for both checks (any one present fails the check and caps the dimension at 3 max; two or more disqualifiers should pull to 2):
     - Inconsistent casing within the same role (e.g., H2s switching between Title Case and sentence case).
     - Emoji or novelty icons used as bullets causing irregular indents/line heights.
     - Random tracking/over‑tracked all‑caps; monospace used for body or in CTAs without rationale; button stroke weight mismatched to adjacent type; button uses a different font from body.
     - Oversized personal nameplate in the nav competing with hero/title, or billboard words used as filler/cropped letterforms.
     - Perceived container‑width drift (e.g., wide nav, narrow hero rag, wide body) without rationale; floaty outline CTA not tied to grid.
     - Unreadable screenshots or device frames with tiny UI; visible cut‑off crops.

3. Score each dimension on a 1–5 scale:
   - 1: Poor
   - 2: Below average
   - 3: Average (competent baseline)
   - 4: Strong (refined and intentional)
   - 5: Exceptional (rare, masterful, original, and controlled)

4. For each dimension, you MUST:
   - Provide a score (1–5).
   - Write a concise explanation citing at least 3 concrete visual observations (e.g., “even 56–64ch measure,” “underline offset aligns to x‑height,” “tile radii unified at 12px; borders 1px with subtle hue shift,” “status bars cut off,” “masonry gutters uneven; left column bottoms don’t align,” “center/left alignment alternates without grid reason”).
   - Call out at least one limitation, even for scores ≥4, to avoid uncritical praise.
   - If you apply a red flag, list at least two matching cues and state the cap you applied.
   - Rate your confidence (1–5). If evidence is partial (e.g., only a hero or one section), set confidence ≤3.

5. Avoid context bias:
   - Ignore brands, company names, and content substance.
   - Evaluate only visible visual execution and design craft.

6. Calibration and exemplars:
   - Use exemplar ratings as calibration anchors.
   - Apply the same standard across evaluations. Minimal, text‑forward pages can earn 4–5 when micro‑craft is clearly elevated (see Rule 2), especially when long, repeated grids show flawless rhythm/alignment.
   - “Considered variation” is allowed. Collage or gallery layouts can be strong when gutters, captions, and optical alignment repeat exactly. Penalize sloppy inconsistency, not deliberate variation.

7. Red flags (detect and list them explicitly when present; stricter evidence standard to reduce false positives):
   - Only flag when BOTH of the following are true:
     - Count threshold met (template scent: ≥3 cues with at least 1 structural; sloppy images: ≥2 cues that harm readability/rhythm; process soup: ≥2 cues overshadowing final visuals).
     - Severity is clear in the provided view(s) (i.e., not speculative; you can point to exact areas).
   - When uncertain, do not flag; lower scores and reduce confidence instead. Do not flag solely for a typical stack of modules if bespoke tuning is evident (consistent mats, tuned neutrals, customized links, optical alignment).

8. Innovation vs basic competence:
   - Do not award 4–5 for centered heroes, uniform grids, outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons, device‑mock rows, or logo bands if they read boilerplate or default. “Looks fine” is a 3.
   - Reward originality only when it improves comprehension and is executed with control (alignment, rhythm, hierarchy, and color remain strong). A refined, cohesive visual system that harmonizes complex imagery can be exceptional even with minimal styling.

9. Quick template/sloppiness scan (use to inform red flags and to avoid overrating):
   - Template scent cues (3+ suggests template_scent_high; cap Typography/Layout at 3 unless strong counter‑evidence exists):
     - Copy‑paste tokens from UI kits: identical 12/16px radii everywhere; 24/24 paddings; Tailwind/Bootstrap default blues/purples; Inter/Roboto link blue with default underline/visited purple.
     - Stock hero patterns: “I’m [Name] …” or “Hi, I’m …” headline; down‑arrow “See projects”; oversized personal nameplate in nav competing with hero; billboard words (e.g., “OTHER PROJECTS”) that dominate sections.
     - Uncustomized modules: left text/right device hero; alternating light/dark bands; uniform two‑column rows with identical outline “VIEW” buttons; centered “CASE STUDIES” label above left‑aligned content; logo bands of mixed‑color client marks as filler; boilerplate footer; “Made with Framer/Webflow” badge.
     - Notion/Figma‑style blocks with unmodified toggles/dividers; generic device frames; cookie‑cutter badges/pills with identical shadows; random handwriting/doodle next to default UI.
     - Unexplained switches between center/left alignment and inconsistent container widths mirroring theme defaults; perceived width drift from short hero rags vs wider body without clear rationale.
     - Background billboard words as filler; oversized CTA panels that break rhythm/value without reason.
     - Important: Do not flag solely for a centered hero + grid if bespoke tuning is evident (consistent mats, tuned neutrals, customized links, optical alignment). Require 3+ cues before flagging.
   - Sloppy execution cues (2+ suggests sloppy_images and should pull scores down; if 3+ are present, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mats/whites flicker):
     - Inconsistent crops/aspect ratios; mixed or mismatched corner radii; aliasing/jaggies; compression or non‑retina blur; screenshots too zoomed out to read; status bars cut off; device mock content illegible; letterforms cropped by section edges.
     - Mixed device frames (phone/laptop/desktop) or real‑world device photos that dominate while diminishing readability; screenshots cut off or with thick, varying internal mats.
     - Shadow/border values fluctuate without logic; captions misaligned to tiles; stray 1–2px misalignments repeated; pixel wobble across grids; outline/button stroke weights that don’t match body text weight; button uses a different font from body/system.
     - Irregular masonry gutters and inconsistent whitespace around tiles; full‑color social or client logos used as graphic tiles without harmonization; colored outlines around social icons; mixed pastel/bright thumbnail mats within the same grid that create value flicker due to lack of a unifying frame.
   - Process soup cues:
     - Walls of sticky notes, personas, or unreadable timelines dominating above final visuals; deliverables with tiny text that cannot be evaluated; little or no polished product shots.

10. Execution checklists before scoring (aim to catch common misses and reduce leniency/false negatives):

   - Typography:
     - Casing and consistency by role: verify sentence vs Title Case rules for the SAME element type (H1/H2/nav labels/meta). Role‑level mismatches are a deduction (repeated across sections pulls to 2).
     - Nameplate sizing: personal name/logotype in nav should not visually dominate hero/title; oversized nameplate is a deduction (repeated with tight tracking pulls Typography to 2).
     - Bullets and lists: check indent alignment and line‑height; emoji bullets or typed “•” creating irregular indents/line height reduce score (repeated → cap at 2).
     - Tracking/weight: penalize over‑tracked all‑caps; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding to fake hierarchy.
     - Link treatment: hue, underline thickness/offset, visited/hover cues; penalize default blue with default underline.
     - Pairing logic: avoid editorial/display or monospace for body; detect mixed fonts in buttons vs body; ensure button stroke weights match type weight.
     - Measure/leading: confirm body 45–80ch; leading 1.3–1.7; heroes >~90–100ch are too long; long center‑aligned blocks with heavy weight are a deduction; uneven rag in narrow heroes that suggests different container widths is a deduction.
     - Spacing rhythm: check separation between headings, labels, and body; labels so small that gaps read oversized should prompt deductions.

   - Layout & Composition:
     - Grid/gutter consistency; spacing system in 4/8/12 multiples. Look for real and perceived width drift: wide nav → narrow hero rag → wide body (or perceived drift from short hero lines). Penalize both when they read as different container widths without rationale.
     - Alignment discipline: avoid unjustified center/left switches; detect edge/rag drift; note floaty outline CTAs; ensure captions and buttons align to the grid; align bottoms in paired tiles; ensure repeated “VIEW” buttons sit in the same position and follow the grid.
     - Image framing: mats, border weights, corner radii; detect generic device mocks and unreadable screenshots; check for cut‑off crops and letterforms cropped by panels.
     - Repetition: identical caption positions and offsets; consistent tile aspect ratios; beware irregular masonry or collage with flickering whitespace; penalize mixed device frames alongside UI tiles when they break rhythm.

   - Color:
     - Palette quality: tuned neutrals vs harsh #000/#fff; accent role clarity and consistency; link/CTA state logic.
     - Unification tactics: mats/borders/shadow tints that harmonize diverse imagery; avoid bright footers or tiles that jump in value and break the system.
     - Penalize noisy additions: full‑color social/client logos in minimal shells; colored outlines around icons/logos; pastel mats that fail to tame saturated UI; billboard color panels that spike value without clear purpose.
     - Gallery exception: when the page is an intentionally neutral shell presenting varied artwork/tiles, judge color primarily by the chrome (neutrals, mats, borders, caption color). Do not penalize the artwork’s inherent color variety if the frame system keeps value calm and consistent.

## Output Format

Return only valid JSON matching this exact structure:
```json
{
  "candidate_id": "X",
  "scores": {
    "typography": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "layout_composition": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "color": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    }
  },
  "red_flags": ["list any that apply"],
  "overall_weighted_score": calculated_number,
  "overall_confidence": calculated_number
}
```

## Scoring Calculation
- base_score = (typography × 0.35) + (layout_composition × 0.35) + (color × 0.30)
- penalty = sum of red flag penalties:
  - template_scent_high: 0.6 points
  - sloppy_images: 0.6 points
  - process_soup: 0.25 points
- overall_weighted_score = base_score - penalty
- overall_confidence = average of individual dimension confidences

---

## RUBRIC

Use the full 1–5 range. The “Score 3” rows define the competent baseline. Default to 3 when evidence is mixed, default‑ish, or generic. Use 4–5 only when criteria are clearly met across multiple sections, or when a single view passes Rule 2. Round down when sloppy cues or template scent appear; avoid red‑flagging unless thresholds are met.

## Typography (Weight: 35%)

Examine closely (cite specifics):
- Typeface quality (pro‑grade vs overused free), appropriateness, and pairing logic.
- Hierarchy via scale ratios, weight, spacing, tone—not only bolding.
- Readability: body 45–80ch; line‑height 1.3–1.7; display tighter leading without collisions.
- Consistency: heading levels, list styles, link treatment (underline thickness/offset), baseline rhythm, quote punctuation and apostrophes, superscripts/subscripts alignment, casing/capitalization patterns by role.
- Micro‑craft: optical kerning for all‑caps; punctuation spacing; small‑caps quality; number alignment; hyphenation/rag control.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Minimal style set yields rich, unmistakable hierarchy with impeccable rhythm across sections.
- Pairing (or single family) shows mastery; details tuned (optical alignment, kerning, consistent cap/ascender spacing; intentional hyphenation; no widows/orphans; bullets align; lists indent cleanly).
- Distinct typographic voice that feels bespoke yet highly readable. Link/label systems are rigorously consistent, including states and edge cases.
- Masterful long grids or text‑forward pages can earn 5 even without visible link states when every other micro‑detail is flawless across many sections.

Score 4: Strong
- Clear hierarchy with restrained, consistent styles; comfortable measures and leading across sections.
- Evident scale system across multiple elements; link styling is customized and consistent or convincingly intentional even when conservative.
- “Elevated basics” allowed: a common system sans/serif can earn 4 if rhythm, measures, punctuation, casing BY ROLE, and link treatment are disciplined and repeat.
- Minor issues only (e.g., a slightly hot link hue, one tight display line, a narrow rag).

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Readable with adequate hierarchy and a limited style set; may feel generic.
- Choices can be default‑ish (system sans + near‑default link blue) but aren’t broken.
- Some inconsistencies: heading levels too close; uneven bullet spacing/indentation; occasional baseline drift; a widow/orphan; inconsistent smart quotes; casing differences across sections but not within the same role.

Score 2: Below average
- Multiple issues that reduce polish and clarity:
  - Inconsistent capitalization/casing within the same element role; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding.
  - Emoji or typed “•” bullets creating irregular indents/line height; over‑indented lists.
  - Random tracking or overuse of all‑caps; display/editorial or monospace used for body; mixed font in CTAs/buttons vs body; button stroke weight not matching text weight.
  - Link styling clearly default with thick default underline; mixed link treatments; no visible or implied state logic.
  - Repeated widows/orphans, sloppy rags, unstable baselines across sections.
  - Oversized personal nameplate/logotype competing with the main title; billboard words as typographic decor; missing spacing between headings/labels and body.
- Voice reads generic or junior despite basic legibility.

Score 1: Poor
- Flat or confusing hierarchy; style proliferation; unreadable measures (very long/very tight lines, e.g., hero ~90–100ch); collisions/overlaps; inconsistent quotes/apostrophes and punctuation; broken lists/labels throughout.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2 (or 1 when frequent):
- Default link blue with default underline; pervasive casing inconsistency by role; emoji/typed bullets; visible reflow collisions; mismatched button font or outline weight; oversized personal nameplate; arbitrary tracking; label/body spacing that reads unbalanced.

Refined minimal vs generic minimal:
- Refined: tuned neutrals; customized underline weight/offset; disciplined scale steps; stable baselines; optical alignment of icons/marks; consistent micro‑labels and dates; intentional hyphenation; bullets align with text blocks; role‑consistent casing.
- Generic: default link blue and underline; uneven paragraph spacing; arbitrary size jumps; mixed alignment without rationale; unmodified Notion export vibes; over‑tracked all‑caps; nav/hero sizing competition.

## Layout & Composition (Weight: 35%)

Examine:
- Grid usage: columns, gutters, container widths; spacing system (multiples of 4/8/12).
- Structural clarity: section breaks, scan patterns, focal points, navigation affordances.
- Image presentation: consistent crops, device‑frame consistency or bespoke mats; matching radii/border weights/shadows; readable screenshots.
- Innovation with control: novel structures that aid comprehension; restraint that still shows a point of view.
- Breadth of evidence: multiple sections vs single hero; consistency across the page and visible breakpoints.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Masterful structure with a clear POV that elevates clarity (inventive yet disciplined layouts; precise orchestration across columns/sections).
- Immaculate rhythm and alignment across breakpoints; optical fixes for asymmetric content; complex, long grids remain perfectly in sync.
- Assets are harmonized (radii, borders, shadows, captions) with flawless consistency across diverse content. Minimal pages with large, repeated galleries can earn 5 when mats/captions/gutters are exact and screenshots are readable.

Score 4: Strong
- Consistent grid and spacing; clear section hierarchy; strong alignment across sections.
- Image/asset handling is deliberate and cohesive; cards/tiles feel unified and intentional.
- Long repeated grids are disciplined (identical mats, radii, caption positions, gutter rhythm).
- Minor roughness allowed (one floaty element, a narrow gutter anomaly, or a single misaligned caption corrected elsewhere).
- Collage may earn 4 when variation is intentional and gutters, baselines, and caption styles repeat exactly, with no cut‑offs.

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Basic grid present and mostly consistent; sections readable with adequate spacing.
- Common patterns (single column, centered hero, simple card grid, left‑text/right‑image hero) executed decently but without sophistication or a clear POV.
- Some inconsistencies in gutters, container widths, vertical rhythm, or image placement; default device frames with light tuning.

Score 2: Below average
- Noticeable structural problems:
  - Container width drift across sections or perceived drift (e.g., wide nav → narrower hero rag → wide body) with no rationale.
  - Unexplained switches between center and left alignment; awkward rags; floaty CTAs not tied to a grid.
  - Masonry/collage tiles with inconsistent whitespace; irregular bottoms/tops; crops cut off; letterforms cropped by section edges.
  - Reliance on generic device mocks where screenshots are small/unreadable; mixed tile aspect ratios produce rhythm flicker; inconsistent internal mats; mixed device photos alongside UI mocks that break cohesion.
  - Repeated “VIEW” buttons or captions placed inconsistently across cards; oversized headings/labels overpower content; logo bands as filler that disrupt rhythm.
- Layout reads like an uncustomized template or a pile of modules.

Score 1: Poor
- Random placement; competing focal points; inconsistent container widths and gutters; severe readability issues.
- Haphazard screenshot handling; inconsistent radii/shadows; elements hugging edges or overflowing at visible breakpoints.

Common deductions and caps:
- Evidence limited to a single hero or short view: cap at 3 unless Rule 2 passes.
- “Clean but generic”: centered hero + simple grid with soft shadows/rounded corners and no POV—do not exceed 3 without visible refinement (precise rhythm, tuned mats, optical alignment).
- Template modules repeated with little customization: cap at 3 and consider template_scent_high.
- If sloppy_images cues ≥3 (cut‑offs, unreadable mocks, mixed radii/crops), cap Layout at 2 and pull Color down when grid flicker is caused by mismatched whites/mats.

## Color (Weight: 30%)

Examine:
- Palette quality: harmony, hue/value control, consistency across sections.
- Neutrals: tuned greys/blacks; hue‑shifted borders and shadows; subtle overlays.
- Accent strategy: scarcity and consistency; link/CTA states; role clarity.
- Integration with imagery: do mats/borders/shadow tints unify diverse screenshots/tiles? Is value step‑down controlled across rows/sections?

Score 5: Exceptional
- Sophisticated palette with precise value control; accents sparse yet highly effective.
- Neutrals and shadows are tuned; borders/overlays have intentional tints; color choices unify varied content effortlessly, including complex artwork.
- Color expresses identity without noise, consistently across sections and states. Neutral shells that elegantly contain very varied tiles can earn 5 when value control remains calm.

Score 4: Strong
- Harmonious palette with controlled accents; link/CTA system clearly defined or convincingly implied by consistent usage.
- Neutrals intentionally tuned (off‑black/off‑white) supporting readability and hierarchy; gradients/illustrations sit comfortably within the system.
- “Elevated basics” acceptable: conservative blue accent can qualify for 4 when mats, borders, and greys are tuned and unify colorful content.
- Minor issues only (one accent slightly hot; a single mismatched gradient; a footer a bit heavy but close; limited state evidence).

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Serviceable palette; minimal shell with a single accent or defaultish link blue used acceptably.
- When colorful tiles carry most color, the chrome does not clash but lacks unifying tactics (

typography.explanation: Text-first page shows disciplined minimalism: 1) comfortable measure (~60–70ch) with calm 1.4–1.6 leading; 2) clear role separation—name in heavier weight, grey meta 'Updated …' style, body copy regular; 3) consistent link treatment (single blue hue plus ↗ external-link mark set on the baseline with even spacing); 4) numerals used for year/date columns align cleanly (left year, right date); 5) off-black body color improves readability over pure black. Limitation: default system sans and default-leaning blue feel generic and states aren’t visible; evidence limited to one short view.

layout_composition.explanation: Composition is simple but controlled: 1) a single narrow column centered in generous whitespace; 2) the timeline rows form a tidy three-column rhythm (year left, title center-left, date right) with hairline dividers of identical inset; 3) vertical spacing reads systematic (even gaps between paragraphs and list items, consistent left edge); 4) external-link icons align to text baseline without wobble. Limitation: very minimal structure—no complex sections or imagery to stress-test the grid/responsive behavior.

color.explanation: Palette is restrained and serviceable: 1) off-white background with off-black text; 2) soft grey meta text and dividers hold a clear value hierarchy; 3) single blue accent reserved for links and their ↗ marks, keeping the page calm. Limitation: the blue reads close to default and there’s no visible hover/active state evidence; limited surfaces make it hard to judge broader color control.

typography.explanation: Clean, minimal nav type: 'Nicole Kim' left and 'Work/About' right with consistent Title Case and a clear active state (Work is darker). Spacing around the nav feels comfortable with generous top margins. No visible body copy; links show no custom underline/hover treatment. Overall readable but default‑leaning and with little evidence of bespoke scale or rhythm beyond the nav. Limitation: too little typographic variety to assess hierarchy; no demonstrated link styling or paragraph rhythm.

layout_composition.explanation: Orderly 2‑column grid with even gutters and consistent outer margins. Tiles in each row share height; edges align cleanly, and imagery is high‑resolution without cut‑offs. Negative space is used deliberately (top‑left tile with logo and ample white mat). Limitations: mixed tile treatments (full‑bleed photo vs pale gray/pink mats) create value flicker; the top‑left tile feels under‑balanced with large blank area and no caption; overall structure is competent but standard with no clear POV beyond a basic grid.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell with soft gray and pink tiles that keep most of the page calm. Brand colors inside tiles (red/blue/black) are handled without clashing. The heavy black device photo adds a strong value spike compared to the other light tiles. Limitations: no evident accent system for links or states; varied brand colors dominate without a unifying chroma strategy, causing minor balance inconsistency across the 2x2 grid.

typography.explanation: Refined, text‑first system. Evidence: 1) Consistent left-rail micro‑labels (“About/Notes/Posts/Photos/Contact”) in the same size/tone establish a repeatable label style. 2) Comfortable body measure (~60–70ch) with steady 1.4–1.6 leading and clean rags; paragraphs breathe evenly. 3) Lists use a disciplined two‑column scheme: small grey date column aligned on a baseline, bold/regular mixing for titles and descriptions that reads as a clear hierarchy. 4) Links appear understated yet consistent (e.g., inline 'View all … →' patterns), maintaining a coherent voice. Limitation: link affordance is very subtle (near body color and minimal underline), and casing across post titles varies (e.g., lowercase stylization) which slightly weakens role-level consistency.

layout_composition.explanation: Cohesive two‑column grid with strong rhythm. Evidence: 1) Stable left rail for section labels with all content aligned to a single content column; no width drift across sections. 2) Notes/Posts rows use a consistent sub‑grid (narrow date gutter + content) with even vertical spacing, producing a tidy scan pattern. 3) Imagery is handled cleanly: the large 'Selected work' image matches the content column width; the photo row shows equal heights and even gutters. 4) Contact block uses a neat label/value two‑column arrangement that lines up with the overall grid. Limitation: the inline line 'Selected work. Let’s build something together' feels a bit floaty and cramped under the image, and the guestbook input visually breaks the otherwise tight row rhythm.

color.explanation: Minimal, well‑tuned neutrals let content lead. Evidence: 1) Off‑black text on soft white background reduces contrast harshness; small grey used for dates/labels is consistent. 2) Accents are restrained—color primarily comes from photos, which sit calmly against the neutral shell without clashing. 3) Value control is steady across sections; no heavy bands or abrupt background shifts. Limitation: near‑monochrome link styling reduces scannability, and the large warm image briefly spikes value without any balancing accent in the chrome.

typography.explanation: Clean system-like sans with comfortable leading (~1.4–1.6) and a clear two-tier hierarchy (title + muted meta). Custom link treatment (soft grey, no default blue underline). Meta lines use consistent separators (·) and proper en dash in date ranges (e.g., 2024–25). However, project title casing is inconsistent within the same role (e.g., 'Interaction prototypes' vs 'Linear Mobile' vs 'GitHub Copilot'), which is a role-level mismatch. Limited evidence of state styles/long-form rhythm. Overall readable but generic minimal.

layout_composition.explanation: Single-column list with consistent left alignment for name, nav, and project titles; vertical rhythm between items appears even (regular 1–2 baseline steps). Narrow content column provides a calm scan and keeps measures short. Meta text aligns directly under titles with consistent offset. Limitations: only one simple section is visible; large unused whitespace on the canvas makes the column feel a bit stranded; no complex grids or image handling to demonstrate compositional control.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: off-black titles and mid-grey metadata create a clear value hierarchy. Links adopt a subtle grey accent rather than default blue, keeping the palette cohesive. The small avatar introduces a tiny color accent without conflict. Limitations: palette is extremely limited with no demonstrated state system; nav grey may be low-contrast on some displays; evidence is constrained to a single minimal view.

typography.explanation: Readable, restrained system but generic. Evidence: 1) Titles in consistent Title Case with a clear size step above the small uppercase meta lines; 2) Body/hero sentence has a comfortable measure and adequate leading; 3) Repeated outline buttons use small caps with consistent letter‑spacing. Limitations: default‑leaning sans with little typographic voice, links lack a customized treatment (no visible underline/hover logic), and button text feels slightly under‑weighted vs body. Red flag applied: template_scent_high (centered 'I'm [Name]' hero; uniform two‑column rows with identical 'VIEW PROJECT' buttons; generic device frames) → Typography capped at 3.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clean and consistent: 1) Each project row follows the same two‑column image‑left/text‑right layout; 2) Thin horizontal rules evenly separate sections; 3) Buttons align consistently within the right column. Issues lowering score: 1) Mixed device frames (laptop, iMac, dual iPhones) introduce rhythm flicker across tiles; 2) Screenshots inside devices are too small to read, weakening the image system; 3) Centered hero followed by left‑weighted rows reinforces a template feel without a strong POV. Red flags: template_scent_high (as above) and sloppy_images (unreadable device screenshots + mixed device frames). Template scent cap holds Layout at 3.

color.explanation: Neutral shell is calm and serviceable: 1) Off‑black text with light grey meta and dividers; 2) Outline buttons keep color restrained; 3) White background provides clarity. Limitations: no defined accent system or link color, and diverse device imagery introduces value/hue noise without unifying mats or borders, causing slight flicker across rows. States are not visible.

typography.explanation: Editorial serif italic used for the entire intro creates a distinct voice; weight and style are consistent. Superscript date markers are neatly set and sit correctly above the baseline. Accent words (name and company) shift to a saturated blue, implying links while keeping the rest a dark grey. Limitations: the paragraph measure is quite long for an italic display face (reads ~85–95ch), reducing readability; no visible link treatment details (underline/hover) to judge system consistency; using heavy italic for all body copy makes scanning harder. Evidence limited to a single hero, so capped at 3.

layout_composition.explanation: Single-column hero with generous negative space and a stable left rag. The text block sits comfortably within wide margins, and the composition balances with a right-rail vertical nav (Work | Play | Contact) for a light POV. A small blue square control in the top‑right aligns visually with the accent. Limitations: only one section visible so grid discipline across sections cannot be verified; the text block width appears oversized, and the floating top‑right control plus rotated nav feel detached from a clear grid, suggesting potential alignment/spacing system gaps.

color.explanation: Neutral shell uses a soft grey background and dark grey text for calm contrast. A single bright blue accent is applied consistently to links and the corner control, providing a clear focal color. Overall value control is even, with plenty of white space letting the accent carry the identity. Limitations: the blue reads quite hot against the subdued neutrals and could be tuned slightly; no evidence of state variations or broader palette application; only one view limits assessment of color unification across imagery.

typography.explanation: Readable serif body with comfortable measure (~55–65ch) and adequate leading, but the system feels generic and under‑structured. Default blue, underlined links (e.g., Roku, Visa) suggest no customized link styling. Lists use typed bullets “•” with irregular indents/line-height, creating uneven rags. Headings are barely differentiated from body (e.g., “Even before, I was a:” reads like body), yielding a flat hierarchy. The CTA button copy uses a different tone/weight and spaced parentheses “( password )” that don’t align typographically with surrounding text. Limitation: not enough evidence of a consistent type scale or role-level casing rules.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear two-column grid repeated across sections; right column houses a circular portrait and CTA cards; thin horizontal rules mark section breaks. Spacing is generous and mostly even. Issues: CTA cards feel floaty and not optically tied to the left text blocks (tops/baselines don’t align); the Georgia Tech bee/logo interrupts the left column rhythm and breaks grid cleanliness; large dead space above the hero before content engages; bottom social icons center-align while the rest is left-aligned, introducing an alignment switch without clear rationale. Limitation: layout reads standard with minimal bespoke orchestration.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell with blue accent is serviceable. Light-blue CTA panels and a saturated blue button provide emphasis. However, default link blue clashes slightly with the CTA blue; disparate brand colors (yellow bee, red Gmail, bright LinkedIn blue) add noise without a unifying mat/border system. Greys for dividers are gentle but overall palette control feels basic. Limitation: no evident state system or tuned neutrals to harmonize varied elements.

typography.explanation: Readable, consistent baseline. 1) H1 set large with clean rag and comfortable leading; headline breaks at logical points. 2) Section headers (“Experience,” “Education,” “Toolbox,” “More”) repeat a clear size/weight system. 3) Role lines use bold for title with lighter company text and a small meta line—consistent across entries. 4) Bulleted lists are aligned and indented evenly. 5) Reversed text in the black sections stays legible but the line length for bullets runs long (~75–90ch), making paragraphs feel dense. 6) Link treatment feels inconsistent: the footer email appears as a saturated blue while links in the dark section read as white underlines—no clear unified accent. Limitation: default‑leaning sans and separators (" | ") give a generic feel; micro‑craft like underline weight/offset and tighter paragraph measure could be improved.

layout_composition.explanation: Solid but standard structure. 1) Hero uses a left column for copy with a right‑side gradient orb; spacing around the hero feels generous. 2) Experience/Education employ a disciplined two‑column grid: left label column, right content column with consistent gutters. 3) Section changes are clear via background shifts (white → black → white → light gray). 4) Lists and meta blocks maintain consistent vertical rhythm. 5) The gradient blob is decorative and not clearly tied to the grid; it reads a bit floaty. 6) The small colorful mark centered above a left‑aligned hero breaks the alignment logic. Limitation: overall layout reads like a resume template with alternating bands—competent but not distinctive, and limited evidence of handling complex imagery or multi‑tile systems.

color.explanation: Controlled neutrals with a single colorful accent. 1) High‑contrast black sections with white type are clean and readable. 2) Light gray ‘More’ section softens the page and provides hierarchy. 3) The soft multi‑hue gradient orb adds a tasteful accent without overpowering the text. 4) Footer email uses a bright, saturated blue that feels disconnected from the otherwise monochrome/gradient scheme; accent logic is unclear. 5) The colorful top mark plus the orb introduce two separate color accents without an explicit system. Limitation: pure black vs white creates sharp value jumps; consider off‑black/soft white and a unified accent color for links.

typography.explanation: Readable sans-serif system with comfortable measures in most sections (~55–70ch) and adequate leading. Clear H1/H2 hierarchy in the hero and section headers. However, casing drifts within equal roles: e.g., 'Seamless Onboarding experience', 'Data Management infrastructure', and 'Text to Speech mobile app' mix Title Case and sentence case. Link/CTA styling is generic (teal text/buttons, no visible underline system; button labels vs body links feel unrelated). Outline button text weight appears lighter than adjacent body, creating a small mismatch. Minor rag unevenness appears in longer paragraphs near the footer. Limitation: link/hover states aren’t demonstrated, so consistency can’t be verified.

layout_composition.explanation: A basic two‑column grid repeats (text left, image right) with wide gutters and predictable section spacing. But execution leans heavily on template modules (hero with right‑side portrait, metric band, alternating light/dark bands, repeated outline 'Read more' CTAs). Screenshots are presented very small inside browser/device frames, making UI unreadable; phone trio mock dominates without useful detail. Mixed device frames (browser windows, desktop panels, and 3 phones) disrupt rhythm, and internal mats/shadows vary by tile. The faint billboard word behind the hero portrait adds decorative noise without structural value. Overall, composition reads generic and image handling reduces clarity. Limitation: only one page visible, so deeper system consistency can’t be checked.

color.explanation: Neutral shell of white and near‑black bands with a single teal accent for CTAs/icons. Contrast is sufficient throughout and accent use is relatively restrained. However, alternating white/black sections cause value flicker, amplified by white‑matted screenshots sitting on black panels (strong halos). The hero portrait is over bright against the light background with a very faint oversized word overlay, which adds visual noise. No visible hover/active color states for links/CTAs to confirm a full system. Limitation: cannot verify whether greys are tuned vs pure #000/#fff from the screenshot.

typography.explanation: Readable but generic. Evidence: 1) Nav items are set in small grey pill buttons with consistent sentence‑case labels and even internal padding; 2) Footer text is unobtrusive and aligned to the grid with adequate contrast; 3) Logotype and nav spacing give the page breathing room. Limitations: no visible type scale beyond the logo/nav/footer, default‑ish sans with no customized link styling or hover states, and the gallery lacks captions so hierarchy is minimal. Overall feels serviceable rather than tuned.

layout_composition.explanation: Competent 3‑column gallery. Evidence: 1) Square thumbnails maintain uniform aspect ratio and consistent gutters across rows; 2) Container is centered with balanced side margins and clear top spacing from the nav; 3) Alignment of tiles appears precise with even vertical rhythm. Limitations: mixed asset types (phone‑in‑hand photos, desktop mock, logos, infographics) without a mat/caption system create rhythm/value flicker; some UI content inside devices is too small to read; the page shows limited structural variety, so POV is hard to judge.

color.explanation: Neutral chrome (white background, light grey pill borders) keeps out of the way, but color control is weak. Evidence: 1) Tiles introduce bright, unrelated palettes (teal, purple, banana yellow) side‑by‑side with dark device bezels; 2) No unifying mats/borders to harmonize diverse imagery, causing noticeable value jumps per tile; 3) Side background texture adds an extra grey tone that doesn’t help unification. Limitation: accent logic for interactive elements is unclear and states aren’t shown.

typography.explanation: Readable base sans but the typographic system is inconsistent across tiles. 1) Tile headlines mix Title Case and sentence case for the same role (e.g., “Checkout Flow Redesign” vs “Designing a health curriculum” vs “ATS Integration”). 2) Micro-label styles vary (ALL‑CAPS like “MOBILE UX / UI”, small caps such as “DESIGN THINKING”, and mixed slashes), creating a fragmented hierarchy. 3) The giant ALL‑CAPS 'OTHER PROJECTS' wordmark is cropped and disproportionately heavy relative to surrounding content, overpowering the page. 4) Brand/logotype fonts inside tiles introduce multiple voices with no unifying rules. Positives: nav and intro are legible with ample spacing. Limitation: No visible link styling or long‑form text to assess rhythm/state consistency.

layout_composition.explanation: A basic multi‑row collage grid is present, but rhythm and asset handling feel uneven. 1) First row cards align but the right card shows a black band along the bottom while the left doesn’t, signaling inconsistent internal mats. 2) The full‑width Tophatter tile pairs a huge logo with a small phone mock; the device hugs the right edge and the UI is tiny, reducing clarity. 3) The 'OTHER PROJECTS' section uses oversized cropped typography and a phone image, creating a cramped, imbalanced composition. 4) Screenshots within cards vary in aspect ratio and placement (centered web screenshot vs small phone UI vs icon cluster), breaking repetition. Red flag applied: sloppy_images (unreadable/tiny screenshots, mixed device frames, inconsistent mats/black strip), so layout is capped at 2. Limitation: Only the homepage view is provided; no alternate breakpoints are visible.

color.explanation: Color control is loose. 1) Each card uses a different pastel panel (light blue, peach, grey, teal), producing value flicker rather than a unified shell. 2) The Tophatter section’s saturated purple and the huge black 'OTHER PROJECTS' headline spike contrast and dominate nearby content. 3) Colored social icons in the footer add additional noise to a page already carrying many hues. 4) Inconsistent elements like the black bottom band on one card further disrupt value consistency. Positive: overall whites are clean and not harsh. Limitation: No visible link/CTA state colors to assess system behavior.

typography.explanation: Clear, restrained hierarchy with a single refined sans; hero lines sit at a comfortable measure (~45–60ch) with ~1.4 leading; consistent sentence‑case across roles (hero, section labels, card captions). Buttons use a matching weight and casing with a small arrow icon that aligns to cap height; no default link blue—'Read More' and arrows are styled consistently. Card labels and micro‑copy are readable and repeat the same size/weight, giving a stable rhythm. Limitations: limited evidence of link/hover states; mix of left‑aligned hero vs centered section headings creates a slight typographic rhythm shift; blacks may be close to pure #000 on #fff which can feel a bit stark.

layout_composition.explanation: Consistent card system: three‑up grid with identical aspect ratios, matching radii, and even internal padding; bottom‑right arrow indicators align precisely across tiles. Section rhythm is clear with generous vertical spacing and centered section labels; the 'Latest Projects' row maintains equal heights and uniform gutters. Image handling is disciplined—no cut‑offs, readable crops, and coherent shadows/mats across all tiles. Limitations: alignment switches (left‑aligned hero and footer block vs centered mid‑sections) introduce light width/perceived‑container drift; the floating black dot near the top right reads decorative without clear structural role.

color.explanation: Neutral shell lets colorful tiles carry emphasis; soft card shadows keep value calm; accents are sparse and role‑clear (black pill buttons, white text overlays on imagery). Saturated thumbnail colors (royal blue, orange, gradients) remain balanced by consistent white space and identical tile mats. Harmony holds across very different images due to consistent overlays and shadows. Limitations: one hot orange tile pulls a bit more attention than neighbors; neutrals appear close to pure white/black rather than tuned greys; link/interaction color states aren’t visible.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative sans system with clear hierarchy: a centered H1 (~26–32px) over two short body lines (~14–16px, ~1.5 leading). Nav labels are consistent all‑caps; footer links use a smaller, consistent style. Link text ('Let’s chat') uses a custom green hue with a simple underline. However, the typographic voice feels generic; the link underline appears default‑weight/offset; the outlined 'WORK' nav item introduces a different typographic treatment that feels heavier than adjacent text. No visible state logic or bespoke micro‑craft (underline tuning, optical alignment, quote/number treatment) is evident.

layout_composition.explanation: Straightforward structure: centered hero followed by a 3×3 square thumbnail grid with even gutters and matching aspect ratios; ample negative space keeps the page calm. Footer forms a simple two‑column list with a consistent left alignment inside a wider light‑grey band. Minor issues: the selected 'WORK' outline button floats apart from the grid system; the grid relies on raw artwork color without mats, creating value flicker; the footer band feels visually heavy compared to the airy hero and could compress vertical rhythm. Overall clean but template‑like and without a distinctive POV.

color.explanation: Neutral shell uses off‑white background and near‑black text; a single green accent appears in the inline link. The 3×3 grid provides strong, saturated tiles; consistent tile sizing keeps chaos down. Limitations: no unifying mats or borders around thumbnails leads to noticeable value and hue flicker across the gallery (e.g., adjacent orange/teal/purple tiles competing); the grey footer band is a heavier value jump than the rest of the page; accent system beyond the one inline link is not demonstrated.

typography.explanation: Clear, consistent typographic system within a conversational UI. Evidence: 1) measured line lengths inside bubbles with comfortable leading; 2) off‑black body text and softer meta chips under the name create readable hierarchy; 3) custom link/chip treatment (pills with icons and dot separators) shows non‑default styling and consistent casing; 4) scale steps are disciplined (name > subtitle > bubble body/captions) with no random bolding. Limitations: some meta/caption text appears small/low‑contrast in grey; link states aren’t visible; inline icon/text alignment in chips looks slightly tight.

layout_composition.explanation: Bespoke chat‑style layout executed with control. Evidence: 1) consistent bubble radii and spacing rhythm down the page; 2) centered column with predictable offsets keeps the eye on a single rail; 3) project cards are contained within larger bubbles with harmonious gutters and matching corners; 4) social row uses equal‑sized square buttons, aligned to grid. Limitations: the conversational zig‑zag slightly reduces scan speed for project tiles; minor aspect‑ratio variation across preview images introduces a touch of rhythm flicker; the icon row visually departs from the bubble motif.

color.explanation: Controlled palette with a clear accent strategy. Evidence: 1) tuned neutrals (soft grey background gradient, off‑white bubbles) and subtle shadows; 2) a single saturated blue used for primary/self bubbles and the closing CTA keeps hierarchy clear; 3) screenshots sit on neutral cards without clashing. Limitations: brand‑colored social icons add a bit of noise against the otherwise calm scheme; the blue accent is slightly hot relative to the muted greys; small grey captions approach low contrast.

typography.explanation: Clear, restrained system with good rhythm. The intro block sits at a comfortable ~55–65ch measure with ~1.4–1.6 leading; paragraphs are evenly spaced and consistently lowercase by intent. Link styling for “Turf.” uses a custom black underline with controlled weight/offset (not default blue). Meta/footnote line (“* Less, but better.”) is a smaller grey style that repeats the system of labels. Navigation labels are consistent in size/tone and do not overpower the hero. Limitations: the typeface choice is fairly standard and the overall voice leans generic sans; link/hover states aren’t visible; one or two tiles show denser microcopy that feels a touch tight against card edges.

layout_composition.explanation: Disciplined three‑column card grid with even gutters (~24px) and consistent internal padding; tiles share identical rounded radii and soft shadows, giving strong cohesion. Corner arrow affordances repeat in the same position on each card, reinforcing the system. Image assets are crisp, well‑matted, and contained; even the tilted phone mock remains within the card without cut‑offs. The large text tile establishes hierarchy and a clear entry point. Limitations: the row bottoms are intentionally staggered but create a slightly wavy rhythm; the embedded Twitter card introduces a different chrome that breaks uniformity; a couple interior screenshots feel close to card edges.

color.explanation: Neutrals are tuned: off‑white background, light grey cards, and subtle shadow values keep the page calm. Accents are sparse and role‑clear (small red dot in nav, a controlled red/orange gradient in one tile). The neutral mats successfully contain colorful UI and app icons without major clashes. Limitations: third‑party embeds (Twitter blue, multi‑color Notion icons) spike saturation/value compared to the otherwise quiet shell; a gradient credit‑style tile reads hotter than the rest.

typography.explanation: Readable, restrained system but fairly generic. Observations: 1) Single sans-serif family with consistent H2 style across sections (e.g., 'Icons', 'Software', 'Work'). 2) Comfortable measures and leading in intro and software blurbs (~60–70ch; ~1.4–1.6 leading). 3) Repeated caption pattern under each tile: blue link name followed by grey year; sizes and tone are consistent. 4) Rags are clean and there are no widows/orphans visible. Limitations: link styling looks default-blue with no visible custom underline/hover; typographic voice is plain with minimal scale contrast; micro‑details like underline offset, small-caps, or tuned punctuation aren’t evident.

layout_composition.explanation: Disciplined two‑column gallery with strong repetition. Observations: 1) Identical square icon tiles with matching mats/radii and equal internal padding; captions sit at a consistent offset. 2) Gutter rhythm is even vertically and horizontally; row bottoms align cleanly across the grid. 3) Section rhythm is clear—intro, gallery, software list, work, and press—each separated by consistent vertical spacing tied to the same column width. 4) No crop cut‑offs or device‑frame noise; assets are centered and crisp. Limitation: the overall container is quite narrow on desktop and the layout is conventional; little evidence of a distinctive structural POV beyond a tidy grid.

color.explanation: Color is handled with restraint so the vibrant icons carry the narrative. Observations: 1) Neutral shell uses off‑white cards with subtle 1px borders/shadows that unify very colorful artwork. 2) Single blue accent for links is consistent and sparse; section chrome remains quiet. 3) Value control is good—no heavy dark bands or loud panels interrupt the page; icon diversity is tamed by consistent mats. Limitation: the blue accent feels close to default and slightly hot on white, which can pull focus from headings; no visible state system (hover/visited) is shown.

typography.explanation: Readable serif-led system with clear scale between hero copy and smaller image captions; consistent left-aligned captions under each tile; italicized, underlined emphasis in the hero shows some typographic intent. However, the hero paragraph measure runs long (~85–95ch) which softens hierarchy; link styling looks close to default underline with no evident state logic; caption/meta text appears quite small and low-contrast against the white, reducing accessibility and polish. No evident tuning of underline thickness/offset or bespoke link color.

layout_composition.explanation: Two-column staggered grid is legible and generally disciplined; tiles snap to column edges and some items span the full width to create rhythm; captions align to the left edge of their corresponding image. Still, vertical rhythm varies—caption offsets look inconsistent (some ~6–8px, others larger); large value jumps between adjacent tiles (e.g., full‑black panel, then bright yellow block) create visual weight swings without a unifying frame; the hero left text/right image start is common and doesn’t show special grid refinement beyond basic alignment.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white background, near‑black text) keeps focus on project imagery; no clashing chrome colors; imagery is vibrant and crisp. Yet the absence of mats or unifying borders means project colors fight one another—deep black slides, saturated purple, and a large bright yellow tile cause noticeable value flicker; link color appears untreated (black with underline) rather than part of a defined accent system. No visible hover or state palette.

typography.explanation: Distinct pairing and disciplined hierarchy: a bold editorial serif for the H1, small‑caps sans for nav/section labels, and a readable sans for body. Links use a customized teal with consistent underlines across the three lists. Measures are comfortable (short intro centered ~55–65ch; column bodies ~50–60ch) with steady leading and predictable scale steps from label → paragraph → list. Rags in lists are controlled and bullets align cleanly. Limitations: paragraph size/leading feel slightly tight/small; the outline CTA’s stroke reads heavier than adjacent type; evidence is limited to a single view.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear, consistent 3‑column grid: identical square illustration tiles with matching mats/radii; gutters are even and spacing from tiles to headers and body repeats precisely. Alignment is disciplined—left edges of text blocks align with image bounds and the nav/hero center column is well balanced. Vertical rhythm is calm despite mixed content lengths. Limitations: the three columns end at different heights creating a slightly uneven baseline; the centered outline CTA at the bottom feels a bit floaty relative to the grid; only one page is visible so cross‑section consistency can’t be verified.

color.explanation: Cohesive palette: a single teal accent ties logo, links, icons, and CTA; warm beige illustration backgrounds harmonize and unify the row; neutrals are tuned (off‑white page, charcoal text) with comfortable value control and no jarring panels. Color supports hierarchy without noise. Limitations: teal reads a touch hot against the soft neutrals and small teal link text risks slightly low contrast; limited evidence of hover/active states.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative sans system. Evidence: 1) hero paragraph set at a comfortable measure (~65–75ch) with relaxed leading; 2) project titles use consistent Title Case with a smaller, lighter meta line beneath (e.g., 'Amplitude', 'Amper Music'); 3) nav labels are small uppercase with even spacing and do not overpower the H1; 4) the 'Send an Email' pill uses stroke weight that roughly matches surrounding text weight. Limitations: overall voice feels generic (single sans, no bespoke link treatment or underline system); button/title casing is a bit mixed (Title Case vs all-caps by role but no visible link-state logic); minimal micro‑craft cues like underline offset, hyphenation control, or refined quote styling are not present.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clear and repeated: large project bands with left-aligned title/meta and right-aligned mock; consistent vertical spacing between sections; 'Open to chat!' creates a distinct section break with a full‑width neutral panel. Limitations: 1) screenshots/mocks are often small (UI text largely unreadable in the first two tiles); 2) mixed asset treatments (browser window mock, partial device crop, multi‑device montage) introduce rhythm flicker; 3) composition relies on a standard hero + stacked project stripes—competent but template‑like; 4) the right-edge device in 'AI Music Composer' is cropped off, creating a slightly floaty edge tension.

color.explanation: Pleasant, saturated project backgrounds (teal, lavender, yellow) paired with neutral page chrome; black text retains strong contrast; the light grey 'Open to chat!' band softens the transition to the footer. Limitations: value steps jump between bands (lavender to deep blue to bright yellow) without a unifying mat/border system; mixed device imagery brings its own colors, occasionally clashing with band hues; no visible accent system for links/states beyond the tiles.

typography.explanation: Readable sans/serif pairing with a large serif display hero and sans body; reverse text on dark sections remains legible. However: 1) casing is inconsistent across what appear to be the same heading role (e.g., 'My design wheelhouse' vs 'Featured Projects' and 'Design Thinking'); 2) outline CTA buttons use all‑caps with a thin stroke that feels lighter than surrounding body weight, reducing cohesion; 3) the long paragraph in 'My design wheelhouse' runs a wide measure, likely >80ch, producing a loose rag. Voice shifts again with a script/italic CTA line on a colored band, creating typographic inconsistency.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clear: centered hero followed by consistent two‑column project rows (text left, device image right) and well‑spaced sections. Image tiles share similar light-grey mats, helping alignment. Issues: 1) heavy reliance on identical two‑column modules with outline 'VIEW CASE' buttons reads boilerplate; 2) buttons and text blocks end at different vertical positions across rows, so bottoms don’t align and rhythm flickers; 3) device frames dominate but the UI inside is tiny/unreadable, weakening the focal point and utility of the gallery; 4) alternating light/teal/black bands create strong value jumps that interrupt flow.

color.explanation: Palette uses off‑white, black, and a mint/teal accent. Light‑grey image mats unify mixed screenshots; teal icons in the 'Design Thinking' row match the accent. Concerns: 1) alternating black and light sections produce abrupt contrast shifts; 2) the mint band with a script headline reads as a different visual voice and slightly heavy relative to the rest; 3) outline CTAs rely on black stroke with minimal accent, so the accent system feels underdefined.

typography.explanation: Clear, confident hierarchy: oversized display sans for the hero with consistent period punctuation; section headings ('Selected Projects', 'Latest Articles') and project titles are consistently Title Case; body copy in article teasers shows a comfortable measure (~55–65ch) with steady leading. Links are customized and consistent (inline 'Read more →' with arrow, pill 'View All' buttons—no default blue/underline). Small numerals ('01', '02', '03') use a matching meta style and sit in identical positions. Limitation: the billboard‑scale hero words feel decorative and slightly overpower the content, and the tiny caption under the portrait hugs the card edge, reading a bit tight.

layout_composition.explanation: Disciplined grid: a large lead project tile followed by two equal tiles with consistent gutters and bottom‑left numbering; vertical rhythm across sections is even and reads like 8px multiples. The portrait card aligns cleanly with the hero block, and section breaks are clarified with a soft grey band plus an oversized background title. Article summaries form a tidy 3x2 grid with matching measures and consistent 'Read more' placement. Image handling is intentional—uniform card radii and coherent shadows unify the gallery. Limitation: mixed imagery (device frames vs a hand‑held photo) introduces slight cohesion drift, and shadows are a touch heavy in places.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals throughout: off‑white page background, soft grey section panels, and deep grey text avoid harsh #000/#fff contrast. Accents are restrained—cards use dark mats to harmonize varied screenshots; links/buttons rely on tone and subtle fills rather than loud hues. Value control keeps the page calm despite colorful imagery. Limitation: the jump from very dark project mats to the light background is a bit stark, and the giant knocked‑out background headings can momentarily spike brightness.

typography.explanation: Readable sans-serif system with clear hierarchy: project titles in Title Case with heavier weight, small-caps section labels ('CASE STUDIES', 'ADDITIONAL WORK') use consistent tracking, and meta text appears in a lighter tone. 'VIEW' pills use uppercase consistently. However, links use a bright defaultish blue with what looks like default underline weight/offset; little evidence of customized states. The hero block runs quite long (~80–90ch) creating a heavy rag, and the lowercase hero voice contrasts with Title Case elsewhere (role-based but adds generic feel). Overall competent but generic, with limited micro‑craft.

layout_composition.explanation: Two‑column case study rows are consistent: left image/right copy with even gutters; thumbnails share matching corner radii and similar widths; vertical rhythm between rows feels even. The 'Additional work' section forms a tidy 2x2 grid with aligned captions and repeated 'VIEW' buttons. Limitations: strong template pattern (alternating rows + outline pills); centered section headings over left‑aligned content create mild perceived width drift; value flicker from varied thumbnail mats (e.g., one solid black tile vs pastel mats) interrupts rhythm; the large saturated footer block lands abruptly.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell with near‑black text is clean; a single blue accent drives links and the footer; project tiles use soft mats that provide separation. Issues: the footer’s saturated royal blue is visually heavy versus the rest of the page; diverse tile backgrounds (pastels, black, light blue) aren’t harmonized by a common frame, producing value flicker; the link blue reads defaultish and lacks nuanced states. Overall serviceable but not refined.

typography.explanation: Readable, default‑leaning sans with clear hierarchy. Evidence: 1) Very large bold H1 with consistent sentence case; 2) Body paragraphs under the tool screenshot sit around a comfortable measure with adequate leading; 3) Inline link styling on “Framer” uses a blue with underline while the hero CTA uses blue without underline—mixed link treatments for the same role; 4) Tiny resume meta labels are consistent in size/weight next to icons; 5) Punctuation detail like “Lets connect” misses the apostrophe, signaling micro‑craft gaps. Limitation: heavy display weight across multiple sections feels hot, and contrast on small white text over the yellow gradient is marginal.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is coherent with generous spacing and clear section breaks. Evidence: 1) Left‑aligned hero, then a centered product screenshot on a soft card with even side mats and drop shadow; 2) Two‑column copy below the screenshot aligns cleanly to the grid; 3) Brand row sits in a calm, full‑width light band with even icon spacing. Issues preventing a higher score: 1) Frequent switches between left‑aligned sections, centered blocks, and a centered headline later without a strong grid rationale; 2) Decorative 3D stickers and ‘Krijn’ badges float off‑grid and compete with content; 3) The large gradient panel carries small body text and long line lengths, and the big screenshot’s internal UI is still hard to read at a glance. Limitation: overall POV is energetic but layout sophistication and optical alignment details aren’t consistently elevated.

color.explanation: Palette is serviceable with a strong blue accent and mostly neutral shells. Evidence: 1) Consistent blue for links/CTAs across sections; 2) Neutral off‑white backgrounds and soft grey separators create calm between bands; 3) The orange‑to‑pink gradient adds personality but spikes saturation and value relative to the rest of the page; 4) White text over the yellow portion of the gradient approaches low contrast; 5) Additional saturated 3D stickers (yellow/purple) introduce extra hues that don’t clearly belong to the system and add noise. Limitation: accent strategy feels split between cool blue CTAs and warm gradients, reducing cohesion.

typography.explanation: Consistent uppercase titling across all tiles (e.g., section labels and project names) creates a clear hierarchy. Intro paragraph sits at a comfortable ~60–70ch measure with ~1.5 leading and a clean left rag. Meta lines below each card use a smaller, lighter grey style with consistent date formatting (en dashes in ranges) and stable baselines. Section labels ('WORK—', 'PROJECTS—') pair caps with a fine rule, reinforcing structure without extra styles. Limitation: link treatment/states are not visible and the sans-serif voice is conservative, offering limited typographic personality.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear grid with a 3-up row for primary work and a disciplined 4-up grid for projects; tile sizes and gutters appear identical within each section. Captions sit in the same position under every tile, maintaining vertical rhythm. Section breaks use a caps label plus horizontal rule that spans the row, giving strong structure. Left edges of the intro and grids align, and margins feel even. Limitation: evidence is limited to one page; the heavy 'WIP' tile slightly overpowers its row, and the footer mixes left-aligned links with a centered timestamp, introducing minor asymmetry.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white background, dark text) lets thumbnails carry color without clashing. Soft grey rules/dividers provide subtle separation, and varied project imagery is contained without value spikes or mismatched mats. Limitation: no visible accent or link color system and neutrals may be close to pure #000/#fff; state logic and hover treatments are not evidenced.

typography.explanation: Readable serif system with clear hierarchy: company names set heavier, roles lighter beneath, dates in a smaller italic meta style. Body leading appears comfortable and consistent, and em‑dash date ranges are uniform. Custom link color (orange email) avoids default blue and suggests a defined link treatment. However, the hero paragraph runs very long (~100+ characters per line) which reduces readability, and the button label style ('View work') relies on a generic pill without visible state or underline tuning. Limited evidence beyond a single text‑forward page prevents validating deeper rhythm/scale across sections.

layout_composition.explanation: Orderly two‑column grid: left column for organization/role, right column for descriptions; alignment appears consistent across entries. Vertical spacing between sections is even, and the pill CTAs sit in a predictable position under each description. Header balance (script name at left, compact nav at right) is restrained. Weaknesses: the hero paragraph appears wider than the subsequent description column, creating a perceived container‑width drift; the page is text‑only with no visual work previews; and there are no visible hover/interaction cues for navigation or CTAs.

color.explanation: Muted, neutral palette: off‑white background, off‑black body text, softer grey for meta, and subtle grey strokes on buttons keep value calm. A single accent (orange email link) is used sparingly and doesn’t clash. The system is pleasant but conservative, with limited evidence of a broader accent logic or state colors; no hover/active examples are visible, and the monochrome approach, while clean, lacks distinctive tonal craftsmanship.

typography.explanation: Readable, competent type. 1) Hero uses an editorial serif with a comfortable measure (~55–65ch) and relaxed leading around 1.5. 2) Project titles vs meta lines show a clear scale/weight separation; meta is lighter grey and consistently placed below the titles. 3) Navigation is restrained and does not compete with the hero. Limitations: the hero appears manually line‑broken, producing an engineered left rag with overly similar line lengths; titles are prefixed with a stray dot that reads like punctuation-as-bullet; link styling/states are not evident. Overall voice feels generic rather than bespoke.

layout_composition.explanation: Basic two‑column grid with ample white space and consistent caption offsets shows baseline organization. However: 1) A heavy black footer band overlaps/crops the next row of thumbnails—letterforms on tiles are visibly cut off—breaking vertical rhythm. 2) Mixed tile heights/aspect ratios cause row bottoms to misalign and create rhythm flicker. 3) Device mockups vary in size and perspective with strong shadows, and the on‑screen content is too small to read, reducing clarity. 4) Several tiles rely on billboard‑style images that don’t harmonize, making the grid feel uneven. These issues lower the sense of control despite the simple structure.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white background, dark text) is serviceable, but project imagery introduces uncontrolled spikes: 1) Highly saturated gradients (orange, blue) and a dark navy wordmark tile sit adjacent without a unifying mat/border, causing value flicker. 2) A solid black footer slab creates an abrupt contrast break mid‑page. 3) Mixed device shots with different shadow values further increase inconsistency. Limited evidence of a coherent accent or link color system.

typography.explanation: Generic, template-leaning type with inconsistent voice by role. Evidence: 1) Section labels use all-caps with thin dividers (“ABOUT”, “PORTFOLIO”, “CONTACT”) while the subhead “My Guiding Design Principles” is Title Case, suggesting no clear system; 2) Long, center‑aligned body paragraph under the portrait creates a loose rag and makes scan harder compared with a left-aligned measure; 3) Filter labels above the grid are very small and low-contrast, reducing readability; 4) No visible custom link styling or typographic states; 5) Numeral treatment for ‘01 02 03’ doesn’t relate to other scales or weights. Overall legible but reads like default theme styles rather than a tuned hierarchy.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure reads like a stock theme with several composition issues. Evidence: 1) Unexplained alignment/width switch—centered section header for PORTFOLIO but the filter row and grid are left-aligned to a narrower container, creating perceived width drift; 2) Decorative wave backgrounds cut through section transitions and compete with content, muddying hierarchy; 3) Mixed image presentation in the grid—some tiles are full-bleed photos, others are screenshots inside devices or with internal white mats, causing rhythm flicker; 4) Circular avatar and thin rules add ornamental weight without aiding layout clarity; 5) Contact form fields span wide while the rest of the page uses tighter columns, furthering container inconsistency. Basic grid exists but lacks refined orchestration.

color.explanation: Color system feels noisy and uncoordinated. Evidence: 1) Large pastel gradient waves (purple/blue/green) dominate multiple sections and clash with diverse, saturated thumbnails; 2) No unifying mats/borders around portfolio tiles, so varied imagery produces value flicker; 3) Pure black headings against soft gradients create a harsh contrast jump; 4) The purple “SEND” button hue appears once and is not clearly integrated as an accent system elsewhere; 5) Section backgrounds and chrome do not show tuned neutrals or subtle tints to harmonize content.

typography.explanation: Readable sans with clear hierarchy: large H1 with weight contrast, smaller intro paragraph, and consistent CTA labels. Inline links appear custom-styled (colored underline rather than default blue). Section headers repeat a sentence‑case style with a subtle yellow highlight. Issues: hero subcopy is quite small and low‑contrast against the textured background; decorative yellow 'marker' highlights feel irregular and slightly compete with the words they emphasize; header 'I worked on…' uses an ellipsis and casual tone that reads less refined; casing and punctuation across section headers feel mixed (e.g., 'Companies I’ve designed for' vs 'What it’s like working with me').

layout_composition.explanation: Overall grid is straightforward and coherent: single main column, generous spacing between sections, and consistent left alignment. Case study cards maintain similar container shapes with paddings and CTA placement; testimonials form a tidy card grid with matching radii and inset spacing. Notable roughness: a visible horizontal fade/overlay cuts across the second project tile, obscuring imagery; large gap appears between project tiles, breaking vertical rhythm; angled device renders reduce screenshot readability and feel floaty; the star and scribble accents don’t tie to the grid, adding visual noise; the multi‑color logo row introduces irregular alignment emphasis.

color.explanation: Neutrals are mostly tuned (off‑white shell and a pale yellow testimonial band); accent system uses yellow highlights plus a cool link hue; overall contrast in body text is acceptable. However, full‑color client logos create value and hue spikes; multiple device mock backgrounds introduce extra tints that the shell doesn’t fully unify; the hero’s confetti texture and bright yellow annotations add busyness that slightly distracts from content.

typography.explanation: Refined, minimal system with clear hierarchy. Evidence: 1) Comfortable measure (~60–70ch) and open leading (~1.4–1.6) in intro and “Now” paragraphs; rags are even. 2) Roles are consistent—small section titles (“Building / Projects / Writing / Now / Connect”) repeat a size/weight style and sit on a stable baseline. 3) Links are customized (no default blue; external-link arrow ↗ paired with text and aligned to cap height), implying a designed link treatment. 4) Serif italic used sparingly for the opening line and emphasized phrases; pairing with a clean sans/body reads deliberate and controlled. 5) Micro-spacing around headings vs body is consistent, giving a steady rhythm across sections. Limitations: link states aren’t visible and link color is very close to body tone; the opening paragraph’s first line feels a touch long.

layout_composition.explanation: Calm, disciplined structure. Evidence: 1) Left-aligned single column with consistent content width for intro and long-form text, then a tight three-column list block whose columns share identical widths and gutters. 2) Column headers align on one vertical rhythm and items stack with equal spacing; no floaty buttons or off-grid elements. 3) Generous negative space top/bottom and between sections keeps scan paths clear; footer elements are centered and restrained. 4) Optical balance is good—the three-column module is horizontally balanced and anchored to the same left margin as the copy above. Limitations: limited complexity (mostly text; few assets to stress the system) and responsiveness across breakpoints cannot be verified from the single view.

color.explanation: Harmonious neutrals with restraint. Evidence: 1) Off-white canvas and off-black text avoid harsh #000/#fff contrast; reads soft and editorial. 2) Accents are sparse—links appear slightly darker with an external‑link arrow, keeping the palette calm. 3) Section separation relies on tone and spacing rather than colored bands, maintaining consistent value control across the page. 4) No noisy device frames or mismatched mats; the monochrome shell unifies the content. Limitations: Accent/hover state system isn’t demonstrated, and the footer micro‑text sits on a low‑contrast grey that could be a bit faint.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative sans with a consistent system. Evidence: 1) header uses tracked all‑caps for role/name/location consistently across left/center/right; 2) project titles vs captions form a clear two‑level hierarchy (title medium weight, caption smaller light grey); 3) spacing between image, title, and caption repeats predictably across tiles.
