Limitations: typographic voice is generic with no bespoke link styling; active nav indicator is a very thin underline with low contrast; captions are quite light/small which trims legibility.

layout_composition.explanation: Basic two‑column grid executed competently. Evidence: 1) even horizontal gutters and consistent column widths; 2) captions align neatly to left edges under each image; 3) generous container margins and subtle horizontal rules create clear sectioning. Limitations: final row leaves an empty right column creating an unbalanced bottom; imagery lacks unifying mats/frames so the grid feels more like mixed photos than a cohesive system; small social icon row feels slightly floaty at the bottom and not tied to the main grid rhythm.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white background, black text, soft grey rules) keeps focus on work. Evidence: 1) chrome is restrained with no clashing accents; 2) grey captions reduce prominence appropriately; 3) social icons in solid black match the typographic color. Limitations: no unifying mats or accent system means thumbnails introduce value flicker (dark leaf/phone shot vs light desk shots); caption grey is close to low‑contrast; overall palette reads safe rather than considered.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative sans-serif throughout; intro sentence is centered with a comfortable measure (~60–70ch) and relaxed leading; Title Case used consistently for nav and the 'Featured work' heading; meta line ('Prior to 2014 – Contact me…') uses an en dash and lighter weight for hierarchy. However link styling is color-only (no underline weight/offset or visible state), the typographic voice feels generic, and scale steps are minimal with little evidence of a tuned system beyond H2/body. Template scent present (centered 'I'm a Product Designer…' hero + standard nav + 'Featured work' label), so Typography is capped at 3.

layout_composition.explanation: Single-column structure with ample white space; the two project tiles share the same container width and align cleanly to left/right edges; vertical rhythm around the H2/meta line is even with consistent spacing between sections. Limitations: module stacking reads boilerplate (hero line → section header → big image tiles), thumbnails rely on a device mock with tiny, unreadable UI, and there is no unifying frame system for imagery. Template scent high (stock centered hero, basic two-tile gallery, minimal boilerplate footer), so Layout is capped at 3.

color.explanation: Neutral white background with dark text provides solid contrast; a single blue/teal accent is applied consistently to links; the thumbnails carry most of the color without clashing with the chrome. Drawbacks: no evident state system for links, the two featured images jump in value (very dark navy tile followed by a light blue tile) without mats or borders to unify them, and neutrals appear default rather than tuned.

typography.explanation: Clear hierarchy and disciplined rhythm: the hero uses a strong sans with a comfortable 2–3 line measure and even leading; section labels ('Selected Works', 'Past Projects') repeat as a small, lighter style; card titles and meta are consistently sized/weighted with Title Case for project names and smaller grey meta below; the name in the nav is small and doesn’t overpower the hero; rags are tidy with no widows. Limitations: typeface choice feels generic and link/state styling is not evident from this view.

layout_composition.explanation: Well-structured two-column grid with generous gutters; project tiles share matching aspect ratios and corner radii; logos sit consistently at the top-left of tiles; the hero balances left text with a right portrait that aligns to the grid; section break before 'Past Projects' uses a subtle divider and consistent spacing rhythm. Limitations: overall structure is conventional and the presentation style differs between sections (captions inside selected-work tiles vs. below past-project images), slightly reducing cohesion.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals (off-black text on soft white) let content lead; pastel tile mats (lavender, mint, light peach) are value-matched and unify diverse imagery; the black‑and‑white portrait avoids color clash; accents are sparse and controlled. Limitations: one saturated orange tile in 'Past Projects' pops noticeably and introduces a small value spike compared to the otherwise calm palette.

typography.explanation: Passes Minimalism Micro‑Craft check. 1) Clear hierarchy: serif display headline with comfortable ~55–65ch measure; body text set with generous ~1.45–1.6 leading and readable rag. 2) Consistent title/meta pairing in the posts list: bold-ish titles followed by lighter grey summaries with identical offsets and line spacing. 3) Customized link treatment (warm brown link color, not default blue) with small editorial cues like the » arrow; micro‑labels like MORE set in a restrained pill with matching letterspacing. 4) Tuned punctuation and casing appear consistent (Title Case for post titles; sentence case in summaries). Limitation: some meta/secondary text and the email placeholder read low-contrast on the warm background; not enough evidence of hover/visited states.

layout_composition.explanation: Single, disciplined column with predictable rhythm; sections (intro, posts card, subscribe, footer) sit on a consistent grid. The posts module shows tight repetition—identical row spacing, soft 1px border, unified 12–16px radii, and a contained top‑right control cluster aligned to the module edge. Left rail icon nav is minimal and visually light, keeping focus on the main column. Limitation: the left icon rail feels slightly detached from the column grid and could read floaty; small contrast in the card’s border/shadow might be too subtle on some displays.

color.explanation: Sophisticated warm neutral palette: off‑white/beige canvas, soft brown/charcoal text, and tinted borders/shadows that create a tactile, paper‑like feel without harsh #000/#fff. Accents are sparse and coherent (links and tiny pills in the same warm family), which unifies the page. Limitation: secondary copy in pale grey pushes contrast; accessibility could be tighter for small text and the input placeholder.

typography.explanation: Readable, minimal sans-serif system with clear hierarchy. Evidence: 1) Large H1 'Hey, I’m Robin' has a strong scale step down to ~16px body; 2) Body measure sits around 55–70ch with comfortable ~1.5 leading; 3) Paragraph rags are clean with consistent spacing between heading and copy. Limitations: link styling appears near-default (single thin underline, same color as body) with no visible states; heading casing shifts from Title Case in the hero to sentence case in 'Nice to meet you' for ostensibly the same role; overall typographic voice is generic with little bespoke tuning.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple two-column grid is applied consistently. Evidence: 1) Hero uses left-aligned display headline with right column intro, aligned to a common top and consistent gutters; 2) About section repeats the two-column structure with text left and a single square image right, maintaining grid rhythm; 3) Generous vertical spacing and a calm footer with elements aligned to left/right edges of the same container. Limitations: structure is boilerplate and shows limited POV; large zones of empty space reduce visual tension; with only two sections visible there’s little proof of complex orchestration or repeated grid discipline across varied modules.

color.explanation: Neutrals are controlled and unobtrusive. Evidence: 1) Off-white background and soft warm-tinted footer band avoid harsh #fff/#000 contrast; 2) Text color is a dark gray/black that reads clearly; 3) Color is largely carried by a single photograph, keeping the chrome quiet. Limitations: link/CTA accent system is unclear (inline link matches body color); no visible states; overall palette feels standard with limited identity beyond the photo.

typography.explanation: Readable, minimal type with decent rhythm. Evidence: 1) Body copy sits in a comfortable ~60–70ch measure with ~1.5 line-height; 2) Role-level casing is consistent—nav uses lowercase, H1 'Shu Ding' is title case, body is sentence case; 3) Links are underlined consistently with a muted hue (not default bright blue). Limitations: hierarchy is very subtle (H1 size/weight close to body), spacing from H1 to first paragraph is a bit tight, and link underlines look default-weight/offset with no visible state logic—overall voice reads generic rather than bespoke.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple two-column layout with a left vertical nav and a thin divider; alignment and margins feel disciplined. Evidence: 1) Stable left column with evenly spaced nav items; 2) Hairline vertical rule cleanly separates nav from content; 3) Content column maintains consistent paragraph spacing and left alignment. Limitations: only a single, text-forward view is visible; large unused right-side whitespace and lack of varied sections/images make the composition feel standard with limited proof of advanced orchestration.

color.explanation: Calm, neutral palette that supports readability. Evidence: 1) Off-black text on soft off-white background; 2) Subtle grey divider keeps value contrast controlled; 3) Links use a restrained blue/grey accent consistently. Limitations: palette is extremely monochrome with no evident accent system beyond links and no demonstrated harmonization against imagery, so it reads competent but not distinctive.

typography.explanation: Large section titles (“Column”, “Webflow Brand”, etc.) are set consistently in a bold grotesk, left‑aligned with even tracking and stable wrapping (e.g., the two‑line “Webflow Dot Com” keeps tidy leading). Small meta rows under each section title repeat the same light, compact style and color across the page, creating a clear role system. Vertical rhythm between title → meta → grid is consistent, with generous spacing that repeats module to module. The tiny M/L control uses the same micro‑type treatment, reinforcing cohesion. Limitations: very little body copy and no visible link/state styling to judge; headings rely on scale more than nuanced typographic contrast; one or two wrapped headings feel a bit abrupt in break points.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is disciplined: each section is introduced by a left‑anchored headline and thin divider line, then a dense, well‑guttered tile grid. Tile sizes are largely uniform (mostly square) with consistent gutters and aligned bottoms within rows; repeated grids across many sections show strong repetition control. The M/L toggle and meta information align to the same left rail as the titles, indicating an intentional module system. The hero shifts to a centered sticky‑note card, but the subsequent sections maintain a stable single‑column grid with consistent container width. Limitations: mixed tile background values (some pure black next to white) create rhythm flicker; some grids end with a ragged right edge as rows complete, and the centered hero vs left‑anchored content reads as a mild alignment shift.

color.explanation: Neutral chrome (white background, near‑black text) lets colorful project tiles carry the palette. The orange sticky note hero provides a single warm accent that doesn’t conflict with later sections. Overall, the shell stays out of the way. However, the absence of unifying mats/borders around thumbnails means dark and light tiles sit directly adjacent, causing noticeable value flicker; pure black/white contrast in the chrome feels a touch stark; no evident link/CTA color system is visible.

typography.explanation: Readable baseline with a clear sans system. Hero paragraph sits around a comfortable ~55–65ch with ~1.4 leading. However, the H1 hierarchy is spiky—“Rajat” is oversized relative to the rest of the page, visually overpowering the content. The left project list mixes heavy red items with very light grey items at large sizes, creating weight inconsistency within the same list role. Micro‑copy under the screenshot is very small and dense (multiple red 'NDA Protected' links crammed in a single line), hurting rhythm. Nav appears all‑caps while in‑page headings are Title Case, adding voice inconsistency by role. Strikethrough on “User Research” adds noise to the intro. Link treatment seems custom (red), but states are not evidenced.

layout_composition.explanation: Two‑column 'Featured Projects' section lacks alignment discipline: a large right screenshot tile sits far from the left list with significant dead space; the list items ('Kredey', 'EY', etc.) are vertically spaced in large jumps, breaking row rhythm. The caption beneath the screenshot does not clearly align to the tile’s left edge, reading slightly floaty. The 'Creative Canvas' block uses a dotted grid container with rounded border but places two small cards pinned to corners (one angled), which do not relate to the grid and feel decorative rather than structured. The oversized red 'Let's Connect' panel introduces a new container width and a center divider not tied back to earlier grid, causing perceived width drift. Overall composition feels novelty‑led over system‑led.

color.explanation: Consistent tomato‑red accent appears in the hero, project list, canvas border, and footer creating a recognizable thread. High contrast black/white shell keeps text legible, and white buttons on red maintain clarity. Issues: neutrals appear close to pure #000/#fff, reading harsh; the confetti speckle background introduces unnecessary noise. Saturated purple and cyan cards (project tile and angled card) clash with the red accent and aren’t harmonized by mats or borders, producing value flicker between sections. Small red micro‑links under the screenshot are visually hot at that scale.

typography.explanation: Readable sans-serif system with a clear hierarchy: oversized hero sentence, large 'Projects' H2, smaller captions/meta. Link treatment visible via simple underlines (e.g., 'Allbirds' and Press items) with a thin, default-looking underline and minimal offset. Nameplate in the top-left is small and does not compete with the hero. Casing appears consistent by role across sections (section heads title case; body sentence case). Limitations: hero paragraph runs very wide across the container, pushing towards an overly long measure; leading in the small intro paragraph is on the tight side; neutrals are pure #000/#fff with default-ish link styling, giving a slightly harsh, unrefined typographic tone.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clear and scannable: large hero image, introductory text block, a two-plus column projects grid, and a dark 'About' band. Project tiles appear to share consistent aspect ratios with even gutters; captions align neatly under each tile with uniform offsets. The About section forms a left image/right information grid with columns for Services, Clients, Locations, and Press; spacing is adequate and alignment feels steady. Limitations: overall composition follows a very standard portfolio template without a distinct POV; the abrupt full-width black band creates a strong value jump; the 'Contact' button feels slightly floaty under Press rather than integrated into a consistent grid baseline.

color.explanation: Neutral shell lets vibrant footwear photography carry the palette. White page sections with black type read clean and high-contrast; the black About section provides contrast and variety. Color in images is rich and not clashing with the chrome. Limitations: reliance on pure black and pure white (no tuned greys) makes transitions stark; link/CTA color system is minimal (mostly black/white with underlines), lacking nuanced states or accent logic; the switch to a full black section is abrupt and heavy.

typography.explanation: Clear hierarchy and a considered voice. 1) Hero uses a tuned display style with the name in italic/color for emphasis while the role and body copy are lighter weight, creating contrast without shouting. 2) Body measure sits around ~60–75ch with comfortable leading; paragraphs are easy to scan. 3) Links are customized (warm orange/periwinkle with thin, non‑default underlines) and inline emphasis is consistent throughout. 4) Repeated meta/label style under project tiles (small caps/size with dot separators) keeps rhythm consistent. 5) Section headers like “Designing for Impact” reuse a scale and accent color consistently. Limitation: casing/voice drifts slightly across sections (e.g., “What I love. About me.” vs sentence‑case project titles) and link states aren’t shown, so system completeness is unproven.

layout_composition.explanation: Competent single‑column flow with clear sections and generous breathing room. 1) Hero aligns left with supporting avatar on the right; nav aligns cleanly at the top, suggesting a stable grid. 2) Project modules show consistent caption alignment beneath large image mats; metrics/icons line up predictably. 3) The collage section (“Designing for Impact”) keeps even gutters, but tile heights/aspect ratios vary, leading to uneven bottoms and rhythm flicker. 4) A very dark video tile creates a heavy value spike that interrupts the otherwise calm vertical rhythm. 5) The dark band features two near‑identical ‘about’ cards side‑by‑side, which reads redundant and adds visual weight without structural purpose. 6) Several screenshots are quite small, limiting readability. Limitation: more evidence of grid rigor across longer galleries or a clearer card system would push this higher.

color.explanation: Warm, cohesive palette with thoughtful neutrals. 1) Off‑white background and soft greys keep value calm; text appears off‑black rather than harsh #000. 2) Orange accent is used consistently for highlights (name, key words, headings) and small UI details. 3) Pastel mats (light blue, lemon) help unify varied screenshots without clashing; the accent orange ties sections together. 4) Dark section uses a near‑black with warm cream illustrations, maintaining contrast while staying on‑brand. Limitation: the very dark video tile and a few saturated blue/texture tiles in the collage introduce value spikes that slightly disrupt harmony, and dual link hues (orange/purple) can feel a bit busy.

typography.explanation: Readable single sans system with clear hierarchy: H1 'Hi, I’m Saebom!' followed by a shorter descriptive subhead; section headers ('Selected Work', 'About', 'Fun') are consistent and in Title Case; body copy in the About section has adequate leading and a manageable measure. Buttons use a consistent pill shape and weight. Limitations: typography feels generic with no customized link styling (only filled pill CTAs); CTA weight is visually heavy vs surrounding text; small meta lines under project titles are light and close to body size, reducing hierarchy contrast; hero leaves a large void that makes the type feel underscaled relative to the canvas.

layout_composition.explanation: Overall grid is coherent: uniform project tiles with matching rounded radii; consistent container margins; clear section breaks from hero to 'Selected Work' to 'About' and 'Fun'. Issues: oversized vertical gap below the hero before 'Selected Work'; CTAs on tiles float at the far right and vary by label ('Read More' vs 'Contact Me') creating alignment noise; blurred photographic backdrops behind screenshots add visual complexity around the core UI and compete with the content; the 'Download Resume' button sits above the About copy rather than aligning to the text block; the 'Fun' section includes a large 'Coming Soon' placeholder that breaks rhythm.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (off‑white background, black text) is serviceable, but color control is uneven. Project tiles use varied blurred photo backgrounds (cool greys/blues) that introduce value flicker against the neutral page; saturated product photo in 'Lange' and grayscale travel thumbnails create inconsistent color modes within the same section; black filled CTAs are heavy and dominate lighter sections. Limited evidence of a unifying mat/border system to harmonize diverse imagery.

typography.explanation: Readable sans system but generic. Visible casing inconsistency within the same role: the hero headline mixes Title Case ('Stunning Designs') with sentence case ('Thoughtful experiences'); section headers alternate between sentence case ('How we win together?') and Title Case ('Got a Project?'). Links/buttons show mixed treatments—black filled CTAs vs bright-blue text links with no underline and varying placements ('Case Study', 'Coming soon'), suggesting inconsistent hierarchy. Subhead copy under the hero runs a long measure with relatively tight leading compared with the display size, flattening rhythm. Overall hierarchy works but lacks bespoke link styling or a disciplined scale system.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is digestible, but image handling and card rhythm reduce polish. Project section mixes tablet, laptop, and phone device frames; screenshots are too small to read. A bright green project tile has an overlapping laptop mock that breaks the grid and vertical rhythm; 'Case Study' labels appear in different positions across tiles (bottom-left on one, top-right on another), weakening consistency. Tile aspect ratios and mats vary (white card, green panel, light gradient), creating flicker. Spacing between modules is adequate but the composition leans on template-like modules without a clear POV.

color.explanation: Neutrals are acceptable (soft grey sections, dark grey text), but accent strategy feels scattered: bright electric blue for links, black filled CTAs, and a saturated green project panel dominate different sections. Mixed device frames and varied mats (white/green/gradient) are not harmonized by the shell, causing value spikes and visual noise in the work grid. Limited evidence of tuned borders/shadows or a cohesive accent system.

typography.explanation: Editorial serif for H2s establishes a distinctive voice; headings like “Discord Mobile Redesign,” “Discord Communities,” etc. repeat with the same weight/size and generous letter‑spacing. Body copy appears in a clean sans with comfortable measure (~60–70ch) and relaxed leading (~1.5), keeping long paragraphs airy and readable. Meta lines (dates/roles) are lighter and consistently placed, creating a clear typographic hierarchy without overusing bold. Links/CTA text are styled in a subtle custom treatment (non‑default hue with small arrow), not default blue. Limitations: headline casing drifts in the editorial statements (e.g., “Strong opinions, Loosely” vs “Uncompromising Quality, Blazing fast.”), a minor rag/widow appears in one long paragraph, and states/underlines aren’t visible, so system rigor can’t be fully verified.

layout_composition.explanation: Consistent single‑column grid with generous side gutters; each project section follows the same pattern: label + serif title + short intro followed by a full‑width image tile, keeping scan predictable. Vertical rhythm is even—section spacers and the small grid‑stamp motif repeat, and all image tiles share the same left/right alignment and similar aspect ratios. The hero composition is considered (decorative circle texture balancing the left nameblock) and the footer resolves into a precise dark grid of icons/labels with tight alignment. Limitations: one project uses a desk/device photo while others use straight UI, which introduces slight cohesion break; some screenshots are somewhat zoomed out (mobile sheet example) reducing readability; image heights vary causing mild vertical rhythm fluctuation.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals throughout: warm off‑white canvas and soft near‑black text avoid harsh #000/#fff contrast. Accents are restrained and mostly come from project imagery; the shell remains quiet so colorful Discord/Blitz visuals don’t clash. The dark footer (deep navy/charcoal) with muted text shows controlled value step‑down and clean contrast. Subtle textures (dot grid, light gradients) sit softly against the background without banding. Limitations: varied mats inside project screenshots (lavender gradient, dark game UI, photo mock) create minor value flicker the shell doesn’t fully unify; link/CTA color states aren’t evident.

typography.explanation: Mixed type voices reduce clarity: a casual script is used for the hero title and all section headers while body copy is a neutral sans, creating a mismatched tone. The hero paragraph is very wide and center‑aligned (~90–100ch) leading to a loose rag and weaker readability. Work thumbnails place tiny white text directly on photos with low contrast, and the recommendation block packs long paragraphs into a narrow rounded box with small type. Link/CTA styling is not clearly differentiated, and overall scale steps/hierarchy feel ad‑hoc rather than a disciplined system. Strength: basic legibility is maintained and spacing between headers and body is generous.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is understandable but several compositional issues hurt polish: the 3‑up "My Work" cards overlay captions on imagery, making them hard to scan and visually uneven; the rightmost card shows carousel arrows intruding on the tile. The "My Process" tiles contain complex diagrams that are too small relative to their cards, leaving large empty margins and unreadable content. The testimonial section dedicates a large left column to an avatar while the text sits in a floating rounded panel with misaligned slider dots—spacing feels arbitrary. The contact section introduces an arched photo crop unrelated to the rounded‑rectangle system elsewhere, breaking visual consistency. Positive: gutters and overall grid width are consistent across sections.

color.explanation: A warm beige gradient shell provides a distinct mood, but value control is loose: strong gradient bands create background stripes that compete with content and cause value flicker between sections. White cards (process diagrams) sit against warm greige panels without a unifying mat or border tint, increasing contrast jumps. Several captions are white on busy photos, reducing accessibility. Accents (hand‑drawn black underlines and icons) feel stylistically disconnected from the soft gradient theme. Strength: the neutral palette is consistent in hue and avoids harsh pure blacks.

typography.explanation: Clear, disciplined type system across three columns: consistent H2s for 'Projects' and 'Thoughts & ideas', uniform meta/date style in a lighter grey, and comfortable measures with ~1.4–1.5 leading. Repeated list items show stable rags with no obvious widows/orphans. Link affordance uses a consistent '→/->' cue and subtle weight shifts rather than random bolding. Overall voice feels bespoke and restrained. Limitations: links are not visibly differentiated from body (no underline/color change), the H1 'Hello, I'm Rasmus' is understated relative to section heads, and interactive states aren’t visible.

layout_composition.explanation: Strong three-column grid with clear gutters; left and middle columns share width while the right column is narrower, giving a stable hierarchy. Vertical rhythm is consistent—list items, headings, and CTAs respect an even spacing system; CTA tiles in the right column share identical mats and padding. The top baselines of the two content columns align, and the nav/bio/CTA stack in the right column adheres to the same column width. Limitations: the light nav stack with the orange dot reads slightly detached from the grid hierarchy, and the heavy outer rails (dark margins) add visual weight without clear purpose.

color.explanation: Monochrome shell with tuned neutrals: off-black text, soft grey meta and CTA tiles, and a single orange dot accent for a subtle identity. Value control is calm—no harsh #000/#fff clashes—and grey mats unify the few UI elements present. Color is sparse and consistent, allowing content to lead. Limitations: link color is indistinguishable from body text, and the orange accent is used once without reinforcing cues elsewhere, slightly weakening the color system’s role clarity.

typography.explanation: Clear, consistent hierarchy across hero, section labels, meta, and titles. Observations: 1) Hero headline set in a robust sans with even rag and comfortable line-height; no collisions. 2) Body copy under hero reads ~60–70ch with ~1.5 leading; spacing above/below paragraphs is consistent. 3) Repeated project meta style (small all-caps badge + light label) sits identically above each title, demonstrating a controlled scale system. 4) Links like “See All Work” and project titles appear custom-styled (not default blue, weight/colour tuned). Limitation: conservative single-family voice with limited visible states; emoji inside the intro sentence adds a casual note and link hover states are not shown.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is disciplined and repeats cleanly down the page. Observations: 1) Consistent container width from hero through work sections—no width drift. 2) Each project module follows the same pattern (large image tile with matching corner radii and soft shadow, then meta/title/description) with identical spacing offsets. 3) Section header row aligns left/right ("Selected work" vs "See All Work") on the same baseline, indicating grid control. 4) Imagery is crisp and readable; device renders are centered with generous mats and no cut-offs. Limitation: layout is standard (vertical stack) with little structural invention; no complex multi-column rhythm shown.

color.explanation: Harmonious, restrained palette that unifies diverse screenshots. Observations: 1) Off-white background with dark navy text (not harsh #000/#fff) provides comfortable contrast. 2) Pale blue/gray mats behind thumbnails unify visuals and keep values calm; shadows are subtle. 3) A single orange accent (Contact pill) appears sparingly and reads as a clear CTA. 4) Dark mobile shot is balanced by the light mat so it doesn’t spike value. Limitation: limited evidence of interactive color states and broader palette range; overall palette is conservative.

typography.explanation: Readable, with a clear hierarchy but mostly elevated basics rather than refined micro‑craft. Evidence: 1) Hero uses very large all‑caps grotesk on a textured maroon panel—legible and confident. 2) Subhead in small all‑caps with period separators repeats consistently. 3) Project captions under each tile repeat: project name left, one‑line description, pipe and year—roles are distinguishable. Rough edges: a) Scale jump is extreme (billboard‑sized H1 vs very small captions), which flattens intermediate hierarchy. b) Links in the footer appear black with default underlines and no visible state logic. c) No visible tuning of rags/measure; body copy is sparse and on the small side. Overall competent but not showing strong micro‑typographic finesse.

layout_composition.explanation: Cohesive single‑column structure with a distinctive collage POV executed consistently. Evidence: 1) Consistent content width for all three project tiles; equal left/right margins and even vertical spacing. 2) Captions align to the left edge of their corresponding tiles with a consistent offset, providing a reliable scan path. 3) Full‑bleed hero with a patterned divider creates a clear section break and sets a unique identity carried into the collage mats (tape, paper textures). Minor issues: a) First two projects use device frames/small screenshots that are not readable, reducing information density. b) Tile heights vary noticeably, creating a slightly uneven vertical rhythm. c) The bottom “Made in Framer” badge adds a small floating element that disrupts the otherwise clean footer edge.

color.explanation: Color shows personality while staying controlled. Evidence: 1) Deep burgundy hero pairs with olive patterned band—distinctive but balanced by a neutral white page shell. 2) Project collages use warm paper textures (beige/green/maroon) that harmonize the diverse screenshots. 3) Text color stays near off‑black/grey for captions, keeping emphasis on imagery. Limitations: the olive doodle stripe is high in saturation/value compared to the rest and can feel a touch disconnected; link/CTA color system is not clearly defined (footer links look like plain black underlines, no visible states).

typography.explanation: Readable sans system with a clear scale from hero → card titles → meta. Positives: body copy under each card sits at a comfortable measure with ~1.4–1.6 leading; meta labels and year/company rows repeat consistently; off‑black text on a warm neutral background improves contrast without harshness. Issues keeping it at 3: (1) capitalization/casing varies by the same role—e.g., “First Draft relaunch,” “Account settings,” “Move management,” and “Museum AR/VR/MI scheduler” mix sentence case, title case, and acronyms; (2) tag casing is inconsistent—‘SHIPPED’ pill in all‑caps sits next to ‘Case study’ in title/sentence case; (3) hero headline effect uses a blurred duplicate wordmark (“Hello, I’m Tammy”) that muddies readability and feels decorative; (4) link styling/states aren’t evident, so hierarchy relies almost entirely on weight/scale. Overall, competent but not meticulously tuned.

layout_composition.explanation: Strong, disciplined 3‑column grid with consistent gutters and identical card widths across many rows; vertical rhythm repeats—thumbnail → title + pill → description → meta are spaced evenly on every card; rounded tile radii and internal mats are consistent, avoiding cut‑offs and stray alignments. The hero comp balances a left text column with a right profile card aligned to the same grid. Minor roughness: the hero’s blurred line forms a heavy value blob compared to the otherwise crisp system; a few thumbnails contain small device UI that is not readable at this scale; mixed thumbnail background values (dark green beside light pastels) introduce slight rhythm flicker. Still, the structure shows control and intention across the page.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals (warm off‑white page, off‑black text) keep the canvas calm. Colored mats on thumbnails are generally muted and cohesive, helping unify varied screenshots; chips/badges use soft greys/greens that don’t shout. The accent palette feels intentional and supports hierarchy without overuse. Limitations: a few tiles skew very dark (deep green) or saturated (yellow/orange) adjacent to pale tiles, causing value spikes; the blurred black hero phrase adds a heavy dark patch that slightly fights the otherwise gentle palette. Overall harmony remains strong.

typography.explanation: Readable single‑family sans throughout; hero H1 'I am Jiyoung' is clear with comfortable spacing; body copy in the hero sits at an acceptable ~60–70ch measure with adequate leading. Tile captions use a consistent meta style (smaller, grey) and repeat beneath each image. However, the captions are very low‑contrast on white, link/CTA styling is generic (thin outline button with no visible state), and the overall typographic voice feels default. Nav labels ('Work', 'About') and project titles are in Title Case while the hero is sentence case, which is fine but underscores the lack of a cohesive system. Limited evidence of tuned underline/links or micro‑craft like consistent state logic.

layout_composition.explanation: Basic structure: dark hero followed by a two‑column project grid; gutters appear even and margins consistent. But several issues reduce polish: (1) grid tiles mix aspect ratios and treatments (browser‑framed dark UIs, full device renders, and collages) causing rhythm flicker; bottoms across rows do not align; (2) the center‑floating 'See projects' arrow is not tied to the left‑aligned grid, creating a break in alignment; (3) the hero’s right graphic shows cropped text ('Design Should Delig…'), reading as an unintentional cut‑off; (4) one tile uses a full monitor mock with a grey mat while neighbors use flat screenshots, adding visual noise; (5) screenshots are zoomed out and largely unreadable, which weakens the gallery’s utility. Overall it reads template‑like rather than a bespoke, disciplined system.

color.explanation: Pleasant dark green hero with off‑white text provides calm contrast; the body switches to a neutral white shell. Accents are restrained and mostly neutral greys. However, thumbnail mats and device renders use varying grey values and shadow strengths, leading to value flicker between tiles. Color from the screenshots is not unified by a consistent frame/border system, so the gallery feels mixed. No clear link/CTA color system is evident beyond the outline button.

typography.explanation: Readable, orderly type with a clear H1 and consistent card titles. Observations: 1) Hero paragraph sits at a comfortable centered measure (~55–70ch) with adequate leading. 2) Card titles use a consistent Title Case and weight; meta/descriptions are lighter weight for hierarchy. 3) Buttons at the footer use consistent style and casing. Limitations: link styling in the hero appears close to default blue with a default underline; overall voice feels generic (likely system/Inter). Some meta text is quite light, reducing contrast, and there’s no visible custom link state/underline tuning.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clear and consistent. Observations: 1) Two-column project grid with steady gutters and equal card widths; cards repeat the same image-on-top + text block pattern. 2) Vertical rhythm between cards reads even; subtle shadows and card radii are consistent. 3) The closing CTA section aligns to the same content width and keeps a simple left-aligned hierarchy. Limitations: several thumbnails are too small to read, one card uses an angled phone mock while others use flat browser shots, and a large logo-only tile breaks the otherwise consistent preview approach—these introduce rhythm inconsistency and reduce polish.

color.explanation: Palette is pleasant and serviceable. Observations: 1) Soft pastel mats (yellow, orange, mint, lavender, coral) help unify varied screenshots. 2) Neutral shell (white background, off‑black text) keeps focus on project tiles; shadows are subtle and not harsh. 3) Accent use is restrained within cards; no clashing gradients. Limitations: default-looking link blue in the hero and dark filled buttons feel detached from the pastel system; the coral logo tile is heavier in value than neighboring tiles, creating a slight value spike.

typography.explanation: Site chrome uses a single neutral sans with a minimal hierarchy. Observations: 1) Name and role stacked top-left with tight spacing between lines, little scale contrast. 2) Nav items 'Portfolio' and 'About' render as plain text links—no visible custom underline, hover, or accent treatment. 3) No body copy or captions to demonstrate a type system; link color appears default-ish and states are unclear. Limitation: too little evidence of rhythm, link styling, or a repeatable scale; overall reads generic.

layout_composition.explanation: Two-column collage lacks cohesion. Observations: 1) Mixed tile aspect ratios produce uneven row bottoms and vertical rhythm (e.g., tall 'bud.com' iMac tile vs shorter laptop/phone tile beside it). 2) Asset handling varies—raw screenshots, angled device renders, slide deck cover, and a real-world photo—causing inconsistent framing. 3) Internal mats differ widely (full-bleed images next to screenshots with large white bezels), and device frames change (iMac, laptop, phones), breaking repetition. Red flag applied: sloppy_images (≥3 cues); layout capped at 2. Limitation: needs consistent tile ratios and unified framing to stabilize the grid.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell but no unifying color system across tiles. Observations: 1) Extreme value swings—black hero graphic, bright orange UI, blue/gold architectural photo, and monochrome poster—without mats or borders to harmonize. 2) Mixed device bezels (black iMac frame, silver laptop, white phones) add additional uncontrolled color/values. 3) Header/nav provide no accent or state color guidance, so the page relies on disparate project colors that flicker. Limitation: introduce consistent mats/borders and a restrained accent to unify diverse imagery.
